div.p: Hi I'm Marisa McFadden and I'm a writing instructor here at DeSales University
for the access program and I'm going to talk to you today
about plagiarism and what it is specifically.
Plagiarism is when you claim someone else's ideas as your own and it's a big problem
across college campuses throughout the country because we all have access to the Internet,
the television and lots of material at college libraries.
And so when we want to get an answer to a question, it's right there at our finger tips.
The issue arises when we don't give credit to the source that we got the answer from.
So when we find out material or we find ideas interesting and we share them with others,
it's important that we give credit to the source material or the source of those ideas.
So if I read a New York Times article and I want to share the contents of that article
with a friend of mine, it would be unintentionally plagiarizing if I failed
to mention or forgot to mention where the article came from.
And for me to avoid plagiarism I would just say "Oh and by the way,
I read that in the New York Times."
In an academic setting you'd do it in a more formal way
by following a style guide like MLA or APA .
You'll learn about those in your EN103 and EN104 classes.
There are resources around the campus that can help you avoid plagiarism--
resources such as all the APA and MLA workshops that are offered through the Trexler library.
Check the schedule for the library because they are offered a few times a month
and they're really informative and they're really helpful.
You also have the librarians there to help you and they're willing to talk to you
by phone, by email and face to face.
Your professors are also a good resource for you
if you have any questions about what plagiarism is.
They understand MLA, APA and Chicago Format very well and can help you avoid plagiarism
by teaching you a little bit more about each of those formats.
There's plenty of resources for you to tap into for avoiding plagiarism here at DeSales,
so just log onto ANGEL , log onto the DeSales website, or just ask one of your professors
or a librarian a little bit more about plagiarism.
Thank you for watching.
